title: Steven Tyler asks Donald Trump to stop using song
text:

Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Steven Tyler asks Donald Trump to stop using song Associated Press, AP 10:39 p.m. EDT October 11, 2015 Steven Tyler doesn't want Donald Trump to play 'Dream On' during campaign events. (Photo: Jason Davis, Getty Images for Pilgrimage Music & Cultural Festival) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LOS ANGELES (AP) â€” Aerosmith frontman Steven Tyler is asking Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump to stop using the power ballad Dream On at campaign events. 
Attorneys for Tyler sent a second cease-and-desist letter to Trump's campaign committee on Saturday. 
The letter says that Trump does "not have our client's permission to use Dream On or any of Tyler's other songs and that it "gives the false impression that he is connected with or endorses Mr. Trump's presidential bid." 
Tyler, who is a registered Republican, attended the GOP contenders' first debate in August. 
Attorney Dina LaPolt said in a statement that the letter is not a "political" or "personal issue with Mr. Trump," but one of permission and copyright. 
Representatives for Trump did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
